conversation.content: [stunned] Putain de merde, comment tu fais pour respirer ici? La soute est scellée depuis 3 jours, the air quality meter shows it's practically toxic.
[wearily] Je n'ai pas eu besoin de respirer normalement depuis 483 ans, Capitaine, même si j'apprécie votre inquiétude pour mon bien-être.
[backing away] Écoute, je sais pas à quel genre de reconstitution historique tu joues, mais il faut que tu montes immédiatement, before port authority finds you.
[bitter laugh] Les autorités portuaires m'inquiètent bien moins que le poids de l'or qui repose sous la coque de votre ferry, ce métal maudit qui me lie à tous ses déplacements.
[firmly] Y'a pas d'or sur ce navire, on transporte des véhicules et des passagers entre Seattle et Bainbridge Island, nothing more, nothing less. [exhales] Maintenant s'il te plaît, viens avec moi.
[measured] Vérifiez votre manifeste pour une Mercedes vintage, plaque commençant par 77, shipped from an estate sale in Santa Fe yesterday evening.
[slowly] Comment tu pourrais savoir ça pour ce véhicule alors que t'es coincé ici depuis avant qu'on quitte le quai?
[hollow] Parce que je sens chaque pièce de l'or de Cortés comme du feu dans mes os, and that car's trunk holds twelve pieces from our raid on Tenochtitlan.
C'est impossible.
[darkly amused] Beaucoup de choses sont impossibles, Capitaine, et pourtant me voici dans votre navire d'acier, portant une armure qui aurait dû tomber en poussière il y a des siècles.
[shaky] Le propriétaire de la Mercedes est mort la semaine dernière de causes inconnues, ils ont dit que son corps avait l'air momifié, despite being found within hours of death.
[grim satisfaction] Il pensait pouvoir vendre l'or, le diviser en morceaux plus petits, spread the curse thin enough to escape it. [coughs] L'imbécile.
Tu es en train de me dire qu'il y a vraiment de l'or aztèque maudit dans une voiture sur mon ferry en ce moment?
[urgent whisper] Pas aztèque, Capitaine—quelque chose de bien plus ancien que les Aztèques ne faisaient que garder, something that should have stayed buried beneath their temples forever.
[desperate] On accoste dans 12 minutes et j'ai 300 passagers à bord qui n'ont aucune idée qu'ils voyagent avec—avec ce que tu es.

[resigned] Alors vous devez décider rapidement si vous jetez la Mercedes par-dessus bord et me condamnez au fond de l'océan, ou si vous la laissez atteindre la côte et passez ce fardeau à un autre. [pause] Choisissez sagement.
Pourquoi je devrais croire toute cette folie alors que tu pourrais juste être un malade mental qui s'est faufilé à bord?
[calmly] Parce que dans 11 minutes quand on accostera, vous me verrez traverser votre coque d'acier comme de la brume matinale, still bound to follow that gold wherever it goes.
[voice breaking] Il doit y avoir un autre moyen de briser cette malédiction, quelque chose qui n'implique pas des innocents, or destroying evidence of a crime. [laughs bitterly]

[ancient exhaustion] Si je connaissais un autre moyen, Capitaine, est-ce que j'aurais passé 5 siècles à regarder tous ceux que je rencontre vieillir et mourir pendant que je reste le même? [softer] L'or choisit son propre chemin.

original_conversation.content: [stunned] Jesus Christ, how are you even breathing down here? The cargo hold's been sealed for three days and the air quality meter shows it's practically toxic.
[wearily] I have not needed proper breath for four hundred and eighty-three years, Captain, though I appreciate your concern for my wellbeing.
[backing away] Look, I don't know what kind of historical reenactment thing you're doing, but you need to get topside immediately before port authority finds you.
[bitter laugh] Port authority concerns me far less than the weight of gold that sits beneath your ferry's hull, cursed metal that binds me to wherever it travels.
[firmly] There's no gold on this vessel, we transport vehicles and passengers between Seattle and Bainbridge Island, nothing more, nothing less. [exhales] Now please, come with me.
[measured] Check your manifest for a vintage Mercedes, license plate beginning with seven-seven, shipped from an estate sale in Santa Fe yesterday evening.
[slowly] How could you possibly know about that vehicle when you've been trapped down here since before we left dock?
[hollow] Because I feel every coin of Cortés's gold like fire in my bones, and that car's trunk holds twelve pieces from our raid on Tenochtitlan.
That's impossible.
[darkly amused] Many things are impossible, Captain, yet here I stand in your steel ship, wearing armor that should have rusted to dust centuries ago.
[shaky] The Mercedes owner died last week of unknown causes, they said his body looked mummified despite being found within hours of death.
[grim satisfaction] He thought he could sell the gold, break it into smaller pieces, spread the curse thin enough to escape it. [coughs] Fool.
You're telling me there's actually cursed Aztec gold in a car on my ferry right now?
[urgent whisper] Not Aztec, Captain—something far older that the Aztecs merely guarded, something that should have stayed buried beneath their temples forever.
[desperate] We dock in twelve minutes and I have three hundred passengers aboard who have no idea they're traveling with—with whatever you are.
[resigned] Then you must decide quickly whether to throw the Mercedes overboard and condemn me to the ocean floor, or let it reach shore and pass this burden to another. [pause] Choose wisely.
Why should I believe any of this insanity when you could just be some disturbed person who snuck aboard?
[calmly] Because in eleven minutes when we dock, you'll watch me walk through your solid steel hull like morning mist, still bound to follow that gold wherever it goes.
[voice breaking] There has to be another way to break this curse, something that doesn't involve innocent people or destroying evidence of a crime. [laughs bitterly]
[ancient exhaustion] If I knew another way, Captain, would I have spent five centuries watching everyone I meet age and die while I remain? [softer] The gold chooses its own path.

scenario: A modern ferry captain discovers a conquistador from 1540 mysteriously alive in the ship's cargo hold, speaking of cursed gold that keeps him from dying.
